findings.title: SQL Injection vulnerability in user authentication endpoint
findings.description: Unsanitized user input passed directly to SQL query in /api/v1/auth/login endpoint. Allows arbitrary SQL execution with database privileges.

findings.title: Hardcoded AWS credentials in configuration file
findings.description: Production AWS access keys found in config/database.yml. Keys have full administrative access to production infrastructure.

findings.title: Missing authentication on internal microservice APIs
findings.description: 47 internal microservices lack service-to-service authentication. Compromise of any single service allows lateral movement across entire infrastructure.

findings.title: Unencrypted PII in application logs
findings.description: Customer social security numbers, credit card data logged in plaintext to CloudWatch. Logs retained for 90 days with broad IAM access permissions.

findings.title: Vulnerable dependency: Log4j 2.14.0
findings.description: Application uses Log4j 2.14.0 with known RCE vulnerability (Log4Shell). Public exploits available. Actively being scanned by automated botnets.

findings.title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in admin dashboard
findings.description: Reflected XSS in admin panel search functionality. Allows credential theft for administrative accounts.

findings.title: Weak password policy enforcement
findings.description: Password policy allows 6-character passwords with no complexity requirements. No MFA enforcement for privileged accounts.

findings.title: Outdated TLS configuration
findings.description: API gateway accepts TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 connections. Vulnerable to downgrade attacks.

findings.title: Missing security headers
findings.description: Application missing Content-Security-Policy, X-Frame-Options, and other security headers.

findings.title: Excessive IAM permissions on S3 buckets
findings.description: Production S3 buckets have overly permissive IAM policies. 45 IAM roles have s3:* permissions when only read access required.
